content.question:
<math alttext="H C 3 H 5 O 2 aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus C 3 H 5 O 2 with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="p K sub a equals 4.87" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>p</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4.87</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
The acid ionization equilibrium for <math alttext="H C 3 H 5 O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented by the equation above. A mixture of <math alttext="1.00 liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar H C 3 H 5 O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.500 liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will produce a buffer solution with a <math alttext="p H equals 4.87" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>4.87</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution was mislabeled and was <math alttext="1.00 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> instead of <math alttext="0.100 molar " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which of the following would be true?

choices.label: The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resulting solution would still be 4.87 because buffer solutions regulate changes in <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> regardless of how much <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is added.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resulting solution would be somewhat higher than 4.87 because adding <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is 10 times more concentrated makes the concentration of the conjugate base 10 times larger.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resulting solution would be much higher than 4.87 because the weak acid would be completely neutralized by the larger amount of <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> added.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resulting solution would still be 4.87 because the solution contains a large volume of the weak acid to react with the <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and would maintain the same <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the resulting solution would be much higher than 4.87 because the weak acid would be completely neutralized by the larger amount of <math alttext="N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> added.

skill.text: 6.G: Explain how potential sources of experimental error may affect the experimental results.
